question: 6 (a)
sols_html:
For the first half of the question, the set of functions \(\{e^{2\pi i\omega _nt}\}\) form an orthonormal basis for the space \(L^2([0,T])\).

Using Euler\(^{\prime}\)s formula we can express \(e^{2\pi iw_{n}t}\) as \(\displaystyle \cos(2\pi w_{n}t) + i\sin(2\pi w_{n}t)\)

So the temperature function y(t) can be viewed as a wave-like function with period T decomposed into a combination of sinusoidal waves. The Fourier series represents it as a purely oscillatory components with frequency \(\omega _{n}\). Here the phase is 0.

For the Fourier coefficients \(c_{n}\), since we have y(t) = \(\sum_{n=-\propto }^{\propto }c_{n}e^{2\pi iw_{n}t}\) then we an wirte \(c_{n}\) as

\(c_{n} = \frac{1}{T-0}\int_{0}^{T}e^{-2\pi i\omega _{n}t}y(t)dt = \frac{1}{T}\int_{0}^{T}e^{-2\pi \ i\frac{n}{T}t}y(t)dt\)

statement_html:
A continuous measurement of the temperature in Vancouver, y(t), for \(0 \leq t \leq T\), is decomposed as a Fourier series of the form

\[\begin{aligned} y(t) = \sum_{n=-\infty}^\infty c_n e^{2\pi i\omega_n t}\end{aligned}\]

where \(\omega_n = n/T\).

What important property do the set of functions \(\displaystyle \{e^{2\pi i\omega t}\}\) have? What is the expression for the Fourier coefficients cn in terms of y(t)?
